claim: Thus, the primary objective of our systematic review and meta-analysis was to map the de novo genotypes, sub genotypes, genotypes mixtures and recombinant genotypes then suggest a plausible explanation for the spatial distribution of these genotypes and sub genotypes basing on the historical and recent intracontinental and intercontinental migrations (Fig. 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Intra and intercontinental migrations to show the plausible origin of the genotypes in Africa: Map was generated by using ArcMap 10.7.1 software (https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/10.7/get-started/setup/arcgis-desktop-quick-start-guide.htm).

claim: The article number and reason for exclusion in each screening step are shown in Fig. 2.
title: Figure 2.
caption: Flow chart for study eligibility following PRISMA criterion.

claim: In contrast, the prevalence of genotype C was significantly higher in eastern Africa than in northern Africa (X2 = 13.062, P = 0.0003, 95% CI = 4.6197% to 16.968) (Table 3 Fig. 3a).

claim: None the less, sub-genotype A1 was the most prevalent in proportions higher than any other sub-genotype (168/222, 75.7%) (Supplemental Table S5, Fig. 3b).

claim: Finally, D/E recombinant genotype has been reported in three studies:—two from Niger and one from Kenya. (Supplemental Table S6, Fig. 3c).
